summary: I'm watching the pilot of Killing Eve with my mom and at the scene where Villanelle is going back to her apartment and turns...
body:
I’m watching the pilot of Killing Eve with my mom and at the scene where Villanelle is going back to her apartment and turns around to look at a woman, my mom said “I saw that girl before…” And I thought, yeah she did other shows and stuff, BUT AFTER TWO FUCKING MINUTES SHE YELLED “OH IT’S THE ONE THAT KNOCKED OVER THE LITTLE GIRL’S ICE CREAM!”.

I have now the confirmation that my mom is Lena Luthor, she doesn’t recognize someone if they’re wearing a wig.

reblog.comment:

and the book doesn’t really spoil the show’s mood bc they’re just so different?

summary: Regarding 1x05 and how in control Villanelle is of the situation when she sits and eats at Eve’s place, I’ve always found this...
caption:
Regarding 1x05 and how in control Villanelle is of the situation when she sits and eats at Eve’s place, I’ve always found this bit to be really fascinating because when Eve decides to still dwell on Bill’s death asking “Why Bill” you will hear Villanelle actually sigh and look down at Eve’s hand, lying on top of the prison file. It’s a minute thing but you can catch the critical and structural advantages of Villanelle’s power over the other woman. It’s like watching her reinvent something again and again but in different and more meaningful ways.

I feel that Villanelle knows that she can achieve a certain mutuality between herself and the woman she has set her eyes on because of the existent emotional checkbox - which is that she can “give” her presence to Eve (who we know is highly interested in Villanelle anyway). It’s like an immense demand for visibility, you know? The way Villanelle manages to create a stark contrast to the loss Eve experiences otherwise when she wraps her hand around Eve’s own and squeezes it. It’s interesting that this dredges up a reason for Eve to combat her own feelings too, imo. Because I mean, I don’t want to get into the layers of the “He was slowing you down” line but it’s such an active push-back that - for a moment - there is nothing but them, because even when Eve grabs the knife to try to hurt Villanelle at the end she also feels the connection.

And yea.

I don’t know where I’m going with this. I just really like that the The Touch acts as the lynchpin of their confrontation and that Villanelle is dead-set on it.

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: Killing Eve Episodes 3-4
title: Killing Eve Episodes 3-4
body:
Villanelle’s character is very interesting in the fact that she is able to change her perception to others very easily. Since she has no innate idea of what is socially acceptable, as seen by scenes such as her copying the laugh of the radio host, or telling her “boyfriend” she wants to do something “normal”. This makes her extremely dynamic because she can adapt to her situation, sometimes better than others. This is most prevalent in her interactions with men. In the fourth episode she is seen interacting with both a male and a female assassin. With the female assassin she shows her strength as a woman and they go head to head as both very strong willed characters with an unclear tumultuous history between them. However, this strength, when shown to the male character clearly makes him uncomfortable. In the same way that Bill was shown as being uncomfortable not being the boss to Eve in a previous episode, this male assassin is shown being uncomfortable with Villanelle being the boss as well. When she gives an order to move forward, he is quick to point out that he is the boss, and restates the exact same order. This mirroring of Eve and Villanelle’s power in comparison to the men around them connect the two vastly different female leads in a way that addresses the male complex of power but also makes fun of it. With one specific character, Konstantin, Vilanelle is shown portraying her weakest facade. She is almost portraying herself as childlike, with her handler as almost a father figure. She appeals to him as a child who needs to be controlled but also begs for more autonomy. This dynamic between Vilanelle and the male characters in the show are almost comical in the sense that she just knows how to work the men in her life. The men are easily manipulated by her and she is therefore intrigued by the women, whether it be intellectual or sexual intrigue. 

Also killing Bill was an evil plot point especially just a scene after they made him a lovable queer icon, but that is besides the point.

-Liana

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: Killing Eve, Episodes 3-4
title: Killing Eve, Episodes 3-4
body: As a queer woman, there is a part of my brain that is delighted that this show with several interesting, fleshed-out queer characters aired on such a mainstream channel as the BBC. However, there is also the more rational part of my brain that is not so desperate for any form of representation it can get that groans at the prospect of this program reaching a wide audience that is most likely mostly straight. Being queer, I am able to detect which elements of this particular representation of queer folk is problematic and potentially damaging, take them into account, acknowledge their inaccuracy, and move on, allowing myself to enjoy the salvageable aspects of the show. This ability to separate fact from fiction is not likely shared by the majority of straight viewers. It is for this reason that I become so concerned when new representations of queer female characters fall into harmful stereotypes, several of which are present in this show. It is clear that there is a connection between Eve and Villanelle, though this connection is based in obsession, not love. Although there is certainly a sexual element to their intense interest in each other what with Eve’s prolonged and detailed complimentary description of Villanelle’s appearance and Villanelle calling one of her hook-ups Eve and dressing her in her clothes, that is all that can be said of any potential relationship between them. This is a case of two women being interested in each other, but the interest is devoid of any actual healthy sexual or romantic content. This phenomenon of queer media featuring two individuals whose so-called “love” takes the form of unbridled, dangerous obsession is all too common, and it is disappointing to see it used in such a high quality production. As a queer woman who loves dissecting fictional works, I am very excited to see how Eve and Villanelle’s storyline evolves and eventually culminates, but I am also deeply concerned at how a straight audience will process their unhealthy dynamic, considering the inaccurate idea that lesbianism has its roots in mental instability is already so prevalent.

Although there is certainly a sexual element to their intense interest in each other what with Eve’s prolonged and detailed complimentary description of Villanelle’s appearance and Villanelle calling one of her hook-ups Eve and dressing her in her clothes, that is all that can be said of any potential relationship between them. This is a case of two women being interested in each other, but the interest is devoid of any actual healthy sexual or romantic content. This phenomenon of queer media featuring two individuals whose so-called “love” takes the form of unbridled, dangerous obsession is all too common, and it is disappointing to see it used in such a high quality production. As a queer woman who loves dissecting fictional works, I am very excited to see how Eve and Villanelle’s storyline evolves and eventually culminates, but I am also deeply concerned at how a straight audience will process their unhealthy dynamic, considering the inaccurate idea that lesbianism has its roots in mental instability is already so prevalent.

trail.content_raw: As a queer woman, there is a part of my brain that is delighted that this show with several interesting, fleshed-out queer characters aired on such a mainstream channel as the BBC. However, there is also the more rational part of my brain that is not so desperate for any form of representation it can get that groans at the prospect of this program reaching a wide audience that is most likely mostly straight. Being queer, I am able to detect which elements of this particular representation of queer folk is problematic and potentially damaging, take them into account, acknowledge their inaccuracy, and move on, allowing myself to enjoy the salvageable aspects of the show. This ability to separate fact from fiction is not likely shared by the majority of straight viewers. It is for this reason that I become so concerned when new representations of queer female characters fall into harmful stereotypes, several of which are present in this show. It is clear that there is a connection between Eve and Villanelle, though this connection is based in obsession, not love. Although there is certainly a sexual element to their intense interest in each other what with Eve’s prolonged and detailed complimentary description of Villanelle’s appearance and Villanelle calling one of her hook-ups Eve and dressing her in her clothes, that is all that can be said of any potential relationship between them. This is a case of two women being interested in each other, but the interest is devoid of any actual healthy sexual or romantic content. This phenomenon of queer media featuring two individuals whose so-called “love” takes the form of unbridled, dangerous obsession is all too common, and it is disappointing to see it used in such a high quality production. As a queer woman who loves dissecting fictional works, I am very excited to see how Eve and Villanelle’s storyline evolves and eventually culminates, but I am also deeply concerned at how a straight audience will process their unhealthy dynamic, considering the inaccurate idea that lesbianism has its roots in mental instability is already so prevalent.

However, there is also the more rational part of my brain that is not so desperate for any form of representation it can get that groans at the prospect of this program reaching a wide audience that is most likely mostly straight. It is for this reason that I become so concerned when new representations of queer female characters fall into harmful stereotypes, several of which are present in this show. It is clear that there is a connection between Eve and Villanelle, though this connection is based in obsession, not love. blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: Killing Eve, Episodes 3-4
title: Killing Eve, Episodes 3-4
body:
All I knew about this show going in was that Villanelle was supposed to be a psychopath and assassin and then that there was some attraction between her and Eve, and since this is a Literary Lesbians class I was watching closely for that subtext and how it was portrayed in the show.

Watching the first two episodes, I definitely noticed Eve’s fixation on Villanelle (or female assassins in general) as being borderline obsessive and at least a little gay. Even though this fixation gets her in trouble and eventually fired from her job, she has no regrets, because she believes this mission is the most important.  I feel like Eve has encountered similar cases of murder or assassination in this job, because this obviously is the only time Eve has been fired from this job, it implies that something about this particular case is special to her. And apparently it is just her intense interest in female killers.  The sexual nature of this fascination is also implied when Eve asks her husband if he wants to have sex, and then a few seconds later just starts thinking out loud about the case.  Since Eve’s focus shifts so quickly and fluidly from sex to thinking about the female assassin she is tracking, this scene demonstrates a clear association between Eve’s thoughts of Villanelle and her sexual desire.  

Eve’s attraction to Villanelle is made even more clear in her description to the sketch artist.  She describes Villanelle as having hair the color of “honey,” “catlike eyes,” and so on. Either Eve was extremely entranced by Villanelle’s appearance in the few moments she saw her in the bathroom, or else she has been devoting a lot of time to romanticizing Villanelle in her head after she realized that this nurse from the bathroom was the killer she had been looking for.  

Villanelle also displays a clear fascination with Eve even before she finds out that Eve is looking for her.  I think she has a thing for her hair, and from her interactions with her bosses when they show her her drawing of Eve’s hair, it sounds like someone from her past named Anna may have had similar hair?  This is unclear at this point in the show and may be revealed later, but Villanelle’s attraction to Eve is still definitely explicit.  She tells the lady she is hooking up with in a couple scenes to wear Eve’s clothes, she calls her Eve’s name, and she focuses on her hair.  

I’m interested to see how Eve deals with Villanelle in the next few episodes following Bill’s murder not to sidetrack from my main point here, but BURY YOUR GAYS (OR BIS I GUESS?) MUCH??  That death was unneessary imo, and definitely not what he deserved and I’m still MAD.  Eve now says she wants to kill Villanelle with her bare hands, but there is still definitely a sexual tension between the two of them.  It’s interesting how much sexual desire and violent desire overlap in this situation.  Eve says she wants to kill Eve, but in spite of her psychopathic tendencies and her murder of Bill, her attraction is still there mixed in with this desire for revenge.  Villanelle gives off the vibe that she has never genuinely loved anyone in her life—a vibe which is further strengthened after she promises her ex Nadia that she can trust her now and then runs over her multiple times with her car with calm indifference.   So both women clearly have this unhealthy obsession with and attraction to each other, and I’m not 100% sure how to feel about it.  On one hand, I love seeing all kinds of lesbian characters on-screen.  I think it’s important to have diversity in queer characters and their personalities, likeable and unlikeable, heroic and evil. However, I worry a little bit that this is falling into the trope of linking attraction between women with psychopathy and being a dangerous or unhealthy obsession, rather than something based in trust or love.  

So the jury is still out on whether or not I support the portrayals of the LGBTQ characters in this show.  Apart from Bill, who I liked a lot.  A true icon. R.I.P.
